Award.AwardTitle: Type I: Re-engineering STEM Study Resources for Undergraduate Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Research on academic help seeking suggests that success is affected by how students identify, select, and access potential study resources. Yet, despite these issues, there is very little research on the actual use and quality of study resources at the university level, either in the traditional face-to-face or in an online setting. The project is re-engineering the study resources that are currently available to undergraduate students in introductory STEM courses. Part of this re-vamping involves expanding the conception of tutoring from face-to-face, one-on-one, private, undocumented encounters to also encompass online, many-to-one, public, archived interactions. The idea is to transform the tutoring experience to support effective student learning using networked computer technology by developing infrastructure for delivering online help with data mining capabilities, developing curricular materials for training undergraduate STEM tutors to work in online communication environments, generating usage, satisfaction, and quality measures for study resources, and studying response to collective versus individual help. This project promotes teaching, training, and learning, both of students and for students, as they do their STEM coursework. The resulting resource will meet the needs of students who are not or cannot be physically on campus or visit the tutoring center when they need help. Also, the anonymity afforded by the resource should encourage students who are otherwise reluctant to seek help. More generally, this project supports the transformation of help seeking from a private, individual activity to a collective, social endeavor that reflects how students of today study.

Performance_Institution.Name: Arizona Bd of Regents, aka ASU

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major purpose of this project was to develop a suite of resources that could improve retention and success in introductory STEM courses at the university level. One of the reasons students fail to succeed in such courses is their lack of readiness. This is particularly true for students who take the summer off between semesters of sequential courses. Data over the last four years at a large Southwestern university shows that even "good" students (those who score an A or B) in the first semester of Calculus and then take a summer off before taking the second semester are significantly more at risk of dropping 2 or more letter grades. Our goal was to stem this flow by providing students with opportunities to revisit and review key Calculus 1 concepts and procedures over the summer in a non-invasive, non-threatening manner. Another purpose of the project was to re-engineer our tutoring resources to better serve students who seek help. In particular, we wanted to test whether technological changes (such as monitors displaying organizational tutor center information) and supplemental instruction sessions for students in hybrid and online STEM courses could lead to improved performance and retention. Finally, we wanted to engage students in face-to-face and online STEM courses. Toward this end we studied how students currently engage with the online lecture videos and explored note-taking strategies. This led us to the realization that online courses contain content but often do not connect concepts and engage students. Our goal here was to produce brief (2-3 minute) animation videos that illustrate the content in an educational but entertaining fashion to accompany traditional lecture videos.

 

Intellectual Merit: We have created a suite of resources that are intended to retain students in STEM majors. First, we created a web-based Keeping In Summer Shape (KiSS) platform (https://mathesis.asu.edu:8443/KiSS/secure/auth/login?error=true) to deliver an exercise from Calculus 1 each weekday over the summer to students who took this course in the spring and were planning to take Calculus 2 in the fall. KiSS provides students with opportunities to revisit key procedures and concepts that are essential to Calculus 2. We also provided supplemental instruction sessions for students enrolled in online and hybrid STEM courses. Finally, we created brief animated videos to accompany the video lectures for the online engineering Calculus 1 course. Examples of these videos can be found online: Optimization: (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rT5A5U1g30A), Exponential Growth: (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FdpF9sra-js), Numerical Limits (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=krGpA44RShkO\)  Despite the fact that brief animated videos are popular with students, not much is known theoretically about how students learn from these videos and how these videos can interact with other instructional materials. This project is a first step toward contributing to this need. 

Broader Impact: Instructional environments are very different today than they were in times past. In particular, technology has radically changed the ways students interact with content. The brief animated videos covering key calculus skills and concepts that were created in this project have the potential to engage a diverse population of students and represent a new and trendy pedagogical method to supplement lecture content delivery. By illustrating concepts in a fast-paced visual fashion, the animations appeal to students and capture their interest. Also, the use of humor is something that has not been extensively explored in mathematics instruction and could potentially help students recall information and also perhaps reduce anxiety. The inclusion of such materials in instruction is not limited to mathematics but has relevance for many different subject domains.


Last Modified: 07/29/2016
Modified by: Carla Van De Sande
